summary_points: 1. At Lockheed Martin's May 9, 2025 annual meeting, 86.47% of outstanding shares were represented, and shareholders did not approve proposals 4 (regarding excessive golden parachutes) and 5 (requesting a report on the alignment of political activities with human rights policy).
2.  A significant year-over-year decrease is observed in votes for Proposal 4 from 2024 to 2025.
3. The election of 10 individuals to Lockheed Martin's Board of Directors is effective until the 2026 annual meeting.
1. Elizabeth Whited, Union Pacific Corporation's President, transitioned to Strategic Advisor on July 1, 2025, receiving a $300,000 annual salary during a transition period ending February 28, 2026.
2. Todd Rynaski transitioned from Chief Accounting Officer to Senior Vice President-Strategy on May 8, 2025, with Carrie Powers appointed as his replacement.

3.  Ms. Whited will not be eligible for Union Pacific's annual bonus program after 2025, but her existing equity awards will continue to vest according to their terms, subject to her compliance with the Transition Agreement.
1. On May 7, 2025, Ecolab Inc. appointed Marion K. Gross to its board of directors, who previously served as Executive Vice President, Global Chief Supply Chain Officer of McDonald’s Corporation.

2. At the Annual Meeting on May 8, 2025, shareholder votes for the election of 13 directors ranged from 181,160,648 to 235,721,263 "for", with significant numbers of votes "against" for some candidates (e.g., 55,003,741 against John J. Zillmer).
3.  Shareholders approved amendments to Ecolab's Restated Certificate of Incorporation to limit the liability of certain officers, as permitted by Delaware law, on May 8, 2025.

1. Constellation Brands, Inc. entered into a $500 million Term Loan Credit Agreement with Bank of America, N.A. as administrative agent and other lenders on May 9, 2025, with the intention to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, including debt repayment.
2.  The Term Loans will mature two years after the initial borrowing, if any, occurs, and the commitments under the Credit Agreement will terminate no later than November 7, 2025.

3. The Credit Agreement includes customary affirmative and negative covenants, including maintaining a minimum Consolidated Interest Coverage Ratio of 2.50:1.00 and a maximum Consolidated Net Leverage Ratio (net of up to $750 million of unrestricted cash) of 4.00:1.00, with a step-up to 4.50:1.00 following a Material Acquisition.
1. On May 9, 2025, Booking Holdings Inc. issued €1,750,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of Senior Notes, maturing in 2031, 2038, and 2046.
2. The Notes carry annual interest rates of 3.125%, 4.125%, and 4.500%, respectively, payable on May 9th of each year, starting May 9th, 2026.

3.  The Company has the option to redeem the 2031 Notes before March 9, 2031, the 2038 Notes before February 9, 2038, and the 2046 Notes before November 9, 2045, under specific conditions outlined in the filing.

1. On May 6, 2025, Omnicom Group Inc. held its annual shareholder meeting, where shareholders elected 11 individuals to the Board of Directors, approved executive compensation, ratified KPMG LLP as independent auditors, and rejected a proposal for an independent Board chairman.
2.  Shareholder votes against the Board candidates ranged from a low of 585,513 votes to a high of 22,969,352 votes (as of May 6, 2025).
3. The shareholder proposal advocating for an independent Board chairman was defeated, with 46,852,570 votes in favor and 119,091,578 votes against (as of May 6, 2025).

1. At PepsiCo's 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 7, 2025, shareholders voted against all six shareholder proposals, including proposals regarding non-sugar sweetener risks, racial equity audits, biodiversity risks, and sustainable plastic packaging policies.

2.  Shareholder support for the election of directors ranged from 919,746,560 votes for Ramon L. Laguarta to 998,937,777 votes for Edith W. Cooper, with varying levels of "against" and "abstain" votes.
3. The ratification of KPMG LLP as PepsiCo's independent auditor for fiscal year 2025 saw 1,093,424,839 votes in favor, 85,680,360 against, and 2,615,449 abstentions.
1. At the General Electric Company's annual shareholders meeting on May 6, 2025, shareholders did not approve a proposal requesting a vote on severance payments.
2.  Of the votes cast for the election of directors on May 6th, 2025, the number of votes against ranged from 2,049,042 to 62,087,449, with abstentions and broker non-votes also recorded.
3. All management proposals at the May 6th, 2025, shareholder meeting, including the "Say on Pay" and auditor ratification, were approved by shareholders.

1. AES Corp's stockholders approved the AES Corporation 2025 Equity and Incentive Compensation Plan on May 9, 2025, authorizing the issuance of up to 14,000,000 shares of common stock, plus additional shares based on the Predecessor Plan.
2.  At the Annual Meeting, Proposal 1 (election of 11 directors) received significant "Against" votes ranging from 1,293,362 to 12,772,078, indicating some shareholder dissent.
3.  Shareholders approved (on an advisory basis) the company's executive compensation plan on May 9, 2025 with 487,583,327 votes for and 87,033,955 against.
1. TE Connectivity plc voluntarily terminated its $1,500,000,000 364-Day Senior Credit Agreement, effective May 16, 2025, due to successful note issuances and a prior euro-denominated note issuance.
2.  Following the termination of the 364-Day Facility, TE Connectivity expects to reduce its commercial paper program capacity from $2.75 billion to $1.25 billion.

3. On May 9, 2025, TEGSA issued $900,000,000 in senior notes (4.500% due 2031 and 5.000% due 2035) with net proceeds of approximately $887.5 million (after deducting underwriters’ discounts but before other expenses) to be used for general corporate purposes, including debt repayment related to the Richards Manufacturing acquisition.
1. Union Pacific Corporation held its annual shareholder meeting on May 8, 2025, with approximately 88% of outstanding shares present.
2.  Shareholders voted against a proposal for an amended clawback policy by a significant margin (34,840,649 votes for vs. 429,453,939 votes against).
3. All director nominees were elected for a one-year term ending in 2026.
1. At Uber Technologies, Inc.'s annual meeting on May 5, 2025, shareholders elected ten directors to serve until the 2026 annual meeting.
2.  Shareholder votes on the advisory proposal to approve the 2024 compensation of named executive officers resulted in 1,305,136,543 votes for and 228,773,347 votes against.
3. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was ratified as Uber's independent registered public accounting firm for 2025.

1. MGM Resorts International held its annual meeting of stockholders on May 7, 2025, where all proposed directors were elected and proposals to ratify Deloitte & Touche LLP as the independent auditor and to approve executive compensation (on an advisory basis) were approved.
2.  Significant variations existed in the voting results for the election of directors, ranging from 141,058,658 "For" votes for Daniel J. Taylor to 155,484,363 "For" votes for Donna Langley.

3. While the filing doesn't explicitly state future impacts or risks, the significant variation in director election votes might indicate potential internal conflicts or differing shareholder viewpoints that could impact future board decisions.
1. At the General Dynamics Corporation Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 7, 2025, shareholders rejected a proposal for the Board to publish a human rights impact assessment report.
2.  In the uncontested election for the Board of Directors, the number of votes against individual nominees ranged from 2,065,324 to 22,637,808 out of approximately 210 million votes cast.
3. Shareholders approved, on an advisory basis, the selection of KPMG LLP as the Company’s independent auditor for 2025 and the compensation paid to the Company’s named executive officers.

1. DexCom, Inc.'s stockholders approved amendments to their 2015 Equity Incentive Plan and 2015 Employee Stock Purchase Plan on May 8, 2025, increasing the number of shares reserved for issuance by 3,400,000 and 8,000,000, respectively.
2.  At the May 8, 2025 Annual Meeting, 346,192,494 shares (out of 392,107,501 outstanding shares) were present, constituting a quorum.
3. The Company decreased the size of its board of directors to nine members, effective May 8, 2025.
1. CenterPoint Energy, Inc. completed early tender offers to purchase up to $1,000,000,000 of its and its subsidiary's senior notes on May 9th, 2025, with early settlement expected on May 13th, 2025.
2.  As of the early tender date (May 8th, 2025), significantly more than the maximum aggregate purchase price of notes was tendered, leading to proration for some note series.

3.  The tender offers will expire on May 23rd, 2025, but CenterPoint Energy does not expect to purchase additional notes after May 13th, 2025, because it anticipates accepting the maximum amount offered.
1. Crown Castle Inc. (CCI) reported a $464 million net loss in Q1 2025, compared to a $311 million profit in Q1 2024, largely due to an $830 million loss from the sale of its Fiber Business.
2. CCI expects a $200 million reduction in site rental revenues in 2025, due to higher tower non-renewals and decreased long-term prepaid rent amortization.
3.  The $8.5 billion sale of CCI's Fiber Business, expected to close in the first half of 2026, will be treated as a discontinued operation, affecting future financial reporting.
1. Akamai's net income dropped significantly year-over-year in Q1 2025, falling from $175.4 million to $123.2 million.
2.  Akamai repurchased a substantial amount of treasury stock between December 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025 (an increase of 6,057,512 shares).
3.  Akamai anticipates downward pricing pressure on contract renewals, and has taken on additional debt ($250 million in April 2025).
1. Eaton Corporation plc's subsidiary, Eaton Capital, issued €500 million in 3.625% senior notes due 2035 and $500 million in 4.450% senior notes due 2030 on May 9, 2025.

2. Net proceeds from the note sales were approximately €493.6 million and $494.3 million, respectively, after deducting underwriting discounts and expenses; Eaton Capital intends to use these proceeds for general corporate purposes, potentially including debt repayment.
3.  The notes are subject to redemption at Eaton Capital's option, with specific redemption price formulas and notice periods detailed in the filing.
1. At Intel Corporation's annual meeting on May 6, 2025, 76.3% of the outstanding shares voted.
2.  A stockholder proposal requesting a report on an ethical impact assessment received only 235,770,360 votes in favor, significantly less than the votes against (2,208,866,958).
3. All eleven director nominees were elected at the May 6th, 2025 annual meeting.
1. O'Reilly Automotive Inc.'s Q1 2025 sales increased by 4% year-over-year to $4.14 billion, driven by a 3.6% rise in domestic comparable store sales.
2. As of May 9, 2025, a total of $26.0 billion has been invested in share repurchases since January 2011.
3. A 10% rise in interest rates on commercial paper borrowings would reduce pre-tax earnings and cash flows by $1.5 million annually.

1. On May 7, 2025, IDEXX Laboratories, Inc. eliminated the authority to issue Series A Junior Participating Preferred Stock, and shareholders approved amendments removing supermajority voting provisions and authorizing officer exculpation.
2. At the May 7, 2025 annual meeting, shareholder votes in favor of electing directors ranged from 61,264,568 to 67,067,059 shares, while votes against ranged from 4,375,655 to 7,367,839 shares.
3. The amended and restated by-laws, effective immediately as of May 7, 2025, establish the Delaware state courts as the exclusive forum for certain legal actions against the corporation.
1. D.R. Horton, Inc.'s wholly-owned subsidiary, DHI Mortgage, amended its Master Repurchase Agreement on May 8, 2025, increasing its maximum aggregate commitment from $1.4 billion to $2.0 billion.
2.  The amended agreement extends the repurchase facility's term to May 6, 2026, or earlier termination.
3. The amendment adds Manufacturers and Traders Trust Co. as a new buyer under the repurchase facility.

1. On May 9, 2025, TJX Companies amended and restated two revolving credit facilities, extending their maturities to 2029 and 2030, respectively, and increasing the total borrowing capacity to $750 million.
2.  The amended $1 billion revolving credit facility (maturing May 9, 2030) saw a decrease in its aggregate principal amount commitment to $750 million and a reduction in its interest rate margin.
3.  The company maintained a borrowing capacity of $1.5 billion under the amended and restated credit facilities.
1. Cummins Inc. completed a public offering of $2,000,000,000 in senior notes on May 9, 2025, with maturities in 2028, 2031, and 2035.
2. The offering consisted of $300,000,000 in 4.250% Senior Notes due 2028, $700,000,000 in 4.700% Senior Notes due 2031, and $1,000,000,000 in 5.300% Senior Notes due 2035.
3.  Cummins intends to use the net proceeds for general corporate purposes, which may include refinancing existing debt.
1. Juniper Networks Inc. swung from a net loss of $0.8 million in Q1 2024 to a net income of $64.1 million in Q1 2025.
2.  The DOJ lawsuit against the proposed merger with HPE, commencing July 9th, 2025, could result in an $815 million termination fee for HPE if the merger fails under specific conditions.
3. Merger-related expenses decreased significantly from $28.3 million in Q1 2024 to $9.5 million in Q1 2025.
1. AbbVie's Q1 2025 net revenues were reported as high as $14.276 billion, significantly higher than other reported figures.
2. AbbVie anticipates launching three to five new products over the next three years, and expects several regulatory submissions and data readouts within the next year.

3.  AbbVie completed the acquisition of Nimble Therapeutics for $288 million (including potential future payments up to $130 million) and Cerevel Therapeutics for $8.7 billion (net of cash acquired) in 2025;  a licensing agreement with Gubra A/S included a $350 million upfront payment with potential future payments of up to $1.9 billion.

1. At the CME Group Inc. 2025 Annual Meeting on May 8, 2025, the election of fourteen Equity Directors to serve until 2026 was approved, with varying levels of support ranging from 70% to 90% for individual directors and  a significant number of broker non-votes (23,859,420).
2.  The election of Class B Directors failed to achieve a quorum for Class B-1, Class B-2, and Class B-3, resulting in holdover directors continuing their service until the 2026 Annual Meeting.
3. The ratification of Ernst & Young LLP as the Company’s independent public accounting firm for 2025 was approved with 289,994,511 votes for and 21,300,039 votes against.
1. Alliant Energy plans to invest $3.5 billion in new energy resources (natural gas, wind, and storage) between 2025 and 2028.
2. Alliant Energy's Utilities and Corporate Services Q1 2025 net income increased by $66 million compared to Q1 2024.
3.  IPL faces a December 31, 2025 deadline to either switch fuel or retire Prairie Creek Units 1 and 3 to comply with a 2015 Consent Decree.
1. Solventum Corp's Q1 2025 net income plummeted 60.1% year-over-year to $137 million.

2.  The sale of the Purification and Filtration business, expected to close by the end of 2025, will result in a $100 million non-cash impairment charge in Q2 2025 and reduce future earnings per share by approximately $0.50.
3.  Solventum Corp. had $7.9 billion in long-term debt (excluding current portions) as of March 31, 2025, exceeding its carrying value by $100 million.

1. Philip Morris International Inc.'s Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 7, 2025, resulted in the election of all director nominees and approval of an advisory vote on executive compensation and the ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers SA as independent auditors for fiscal year 2025.
2.  At the Annual Meeting, 1,269,535,339 shares (approximately 81%) of the 1,556,488,205 outstanding shares of common stock were represented.
3. No specific future impacts or risks were mentioned in this section of the filing.
1. CoStar Group, Inc. agreed to acquire 100% of Domain Holdings Australia Limited for approximately $1.5 billion USD on May 9, 2025.
2.  The acquisition's cost increased by approximately $1.2 billion USD year-over-year.
3. The acquisition is subject to Australian Foreign Investment Review Board approval and other customary closing conditions.

1. Norfolk Southern Corporation held its 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 8, 2025, where shareholders elected thirteen directors to serve one-year terms and ratified the appointment of KPMG LLP as the independent registered public accounting firm for the year ending December 31, 2025.
2.  Of the approximately 190 million votes cast for Proposal 2 (Ratification of Appointment of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm), approximately 10.3 million were against the proposal.

3.  Shareholders approved, on an advisory basis, the resolution on executive compensation (Proposal 3, "Say on Pay") with approximately 164 million votes for, and 8.1 million votes against the resolution.
1. Broadridge lowered its fiscal year 2025 closed sales guidance to $240–$300 million, down from a previous projection of $290–$330 million.
2. As of May 9, 2025, Broadridge's Q3 2025 recurring revenue grew 8% (constant currency) year-over-year, exceeding its fiscal year guidance.
3.  Broadridge increased its full-year 2025 adjusted EPS guidance to 9-13% year-over-year growth, as of May 9, 2025.
1. At Dominion Energy's 2025 Annual Meeting on May 7, 2025, all 11 director nominees were elected, with vote counts ranging from approximately 606 million to 633 million votes in favor.
2.  Shareholder approval for executive compensation ("Say on Pay") was also received, with 607,904,627 votes for and 27,023,370 votes against.

3. A shareholder proposal to eliminate non-carbon emitting generation goals from executive pay incentives was not approved, receiving only 9,488,225 votes in favor out of roughly 730 million total votes.
1. Robert A. Profusek retired from Valero Energy Corporation's board of directors on May 6, 2025, in accordance with the company's retirement policy.
2.  At the 2025 annual stockholders' meeting on May 6, 2025, all director nominees were elected, though with varying levels of support ranging from 92.82% to 99.25% of votes cast.
3.  Effective May 6, 2025, Valero granted stock units valued at $200,000 to each re-elected non-employee director, vesting in 2026 subject to a one-year holding period.
1. At Equifax Inc.'s 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 8, 2025, shareholders approved amendments to eliminate supermajority voting requirements.
2.  Significant shareholder opposition existed for some director nominees; Robert D. Marcus received 6,443,309 votes against his election compared to the others who received far fewer.
3.  Shareholder advisory vote on named executive officer compensation resulted in 101,048,125 shares for and 8,737,307 shares against, suggesting considerable support but also noticeable dissent.
1. Smurfit Westrock's total debt increased by $624 million between December 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025, reaching $14,219 million.
2.  The company's effective tax rate for Q1 2025 was 2.1%, significantly lower than the 28.5% rate in Q1 2024.
3.  Smurfit Westrock plans to close multiple facilities, resulting in approximately $287 million in pre-tax charges, with $226 million recognized in Q2 2025, and the remainder extending into 2026.

1. Delta Air Lines and Korean Air will acquire a combined 25% minority stake in WestJet for US$550 million (Delta investing US$330 million for 15%, Korean US$220 million for 10%), as announced in a May 9, 2025 press release.
2.  Following the acquisition, Delta intends to sell a 2.3% stake in WestJet to Air France-KLM for US$50 million, pending approval.
3. The transaction is subject to regulatory approvals;  failure to obtain these approvals poses a risk to the completion of the planned acquisition.
1. Monster Beverage Corp.'s Q1 2025 net sales decreased by 2.3% year-over-year to $1.85 billion, though this increased by 0.7% after adjusting for foreign currency.
2. As of May 8, 2025, $500 million remained available under Monster Beverage Corp.'s share repurchase plan.
3.  Monster Beverage Corp. anticipates capital expenditures (excluding stock buybacks) under $500 million through March 31, 2026.
1. Evergy, Inc. entered into an equity distribution agreement on May 8, 2025, with several investment banks to potentially sell up to $1,200,000,000 of its common stock.
2.  The agreement allows Evergy to sell shares through brokers' transactions, block trades, or other agreed-upon methods, with managers receiving a commission of up to 2%.
3.  Evergy plans to use the net proceeds (after commissions and expenses) for general corporate purposes, which may include investments in its subsidiaries.
1. Alliant Energy Corporation's first-quarter 2025 GAAP earnings per share increased to $0.83, compared to $0.62 in 2024, a greater than 25% increase from the previous year.

2.  Alliant Energy updated its projected capital expenditures for 2025-2028 to a total of $11.5 billion, including resources to serve approximately 2.1 gigawatts of contracted peak data center demand.

3. Alliant Energy reaffirmed its 2025 earnings guidance range of $3.15-$3.25 per share, contingent upon factors including the ability of its subsidiaries to earn authorized rates of return, normal temperatures, a stable economy, and successful execution of capital expenditure and cost control plans.
1. Insulet Corp.'s Q1 2025 revenue increased by 28.8% year-over-year, reaching an unspecified figure, with constant currency growth at 29.8%.
2.  Insulet Corp. faces a $59.4 million judgment and permanent injunction from a lawsuit (as of May 9th, 2025), the impact of which is currently uncertain due to an anticipated appeal.

3.  In March and April 2025, Insulet Corp. incurred a net loss of $47.2 million ($123.9 million loss on extinguishment less $75.7 million from capped call options settlement) from repurchasing convertible senior notes.
1. Expedia Group's net loss widened to $200 million in Q1 2025, compared to $135 million in Q1 2024.
2.  Expedia Group anticipates $40 million in additional reorganization charges in the remainder of 2025.
3. Lodging revenue accounted for 77% of Expedia Group's total revenue in Q1 2025, while air travel only contributed 4%.
1. McKesson's fiscal year 2025 revenue increased 16% year-over-year to $359.051 billion.
2.  The company anticipates $650 million to $700 million in charges for operational efficiency initiatives by fiscal year 2028.
3. McKesson's investments in U.S. growth-stage companies decreased by $137 million in fiscal year 2025, ending with a carrying value of $103 million.

1. At Gilead Sciences, Inc.'s 2025 annual meeting on May 7, 2025, shareholders did not approve several proposals, including those related to CEO pay ratio, independent Board Chair policy, and human rights.

2.  Shareholder approval for the selection of Ernst & Young LLP as the independent auditor for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025, was achieved with 1,041,388,468 votes for and 78,979,344 votes against.
3. Nine directors were elected to serve for the next year at the May 7, 2025, annual meeting.
1. Align Technology's Q1 2025 net revenues decreased by 1.8% year-over-year to $979 million, primarily due to lower average selling prices.
2.  The company incurred a $31.75 million loss in Q1 2025 from settling an antitrust lawsuit, with a court hearing scheduled for May 22, 2025.
3. Align Technology initiated a new $1 billion common stock repurchase program in April 2025.

1. Edwards Lifesciences Corp stockholders approved amendments to their 2001 Employee Stock Purchase Plans (US and International), increasing the total number of shares available for issuance by 5,660,000.

2. At the May 8, 2025 Annual Meeting, all director nominees (Leslie C. Davis, David T. Feinberg, MD, Kieran T. Gallahue, Leslie S. Heisz, Paul A. LaViolette, Steven R. Loranger, Ramona Sequeira, Nicholas J. Valeriani, and Bernard J. Zovighian) were elected.
3.  The advisory proposal regarding the Company’s named executive officer compensation was approved with 412,893,480 votes for and 475,265,224 votes against.
1. On May 8, 2025, Mosaic Co.'s President and CEO, Bruce M. Bodine, sold 180,708 shares of company common stock due to a marital asset division.
2.  These shares were granted before Mr. Bodine's appointment as CEO, and he retains a substantial position in unvested equity awards.
3. The filing states that the information provided is not considered "filed" for purposes of Section 18 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1. Corteva's Q1 2025 net sales decreased 2% year-over-year, primarily due to unfavorable currency impacts.
2.  Corteva incurred $487 million in pre-tax restructuring charges in Q1 2025, with anticipated cash payments of $330 million to $360 million.
3. Corteva projects pre-tax amortization expense to range from $518 million to $632 million annually for 2026-2030, compared to a projected $602 million for 2025.
1. Tractor Supply Co. acquired Allivet for $135 million in December 2024, contributing to a 2.1% increase in Q1 2025 net sales to $3.47 billion, despite a 0.9% decrease in comparable store sales.
2.  As of March 29, 2025, Tractor Supply Co. had $1.39 billion remaining in its share repurchase program, increased by $1 billion in February 2025.
3.  Tractor Supply Co. projects capital expenditures of $650-$725 million for fiscal year 2025, including the opening of approximately 90 Tractor Supply and 10 Petsense stores.
1. Freeport-McMoRan's Q1 2025 net income decreased by $121 million year-over-year to $352 million, primarily due to lower Indonesian sales volumes.
2.  As of April 30, 2025, $3 billion remained in Freeport-McMoRan's share repurchase program, after repurchasing 51 million shares at an average cost of $38.50 per share.
3. Freeport-McMoRan's subsidiary, Cyprus Mines, received a $202 million settlement from Johnson & Johnson in Q1 2025, with an additional $51 million expected by December 31, 2025.
1. West Pharmaceutical Services Inc.'s shareholders now have the right to call a special meeting if at least 25% of outstanding shares support the call.
2.  A high 89.93% of outstanding shares were present or represented by proxy at the annual shareholder meeting held on May 6, 2025.
3. Amended and restated Articles of Incorporation became effective May 6, 2025.

1. Fortinet's Q1 2025 revenue increased 14% year-over-year to $1.54 billion, but the company anticipates a decrease in operating margin for the full year 2025 compared to 2024 due to increased investments.
2.  Fortinet's Q1 2025 operating margin reached 29.5%, a 5.8 percentage point increase year-over-year.
3.  Since the start of 2025, Fortinet has made significant capital expenditures, including a $20.8 million acquisition and a $99.9 million real estate purchase.

1. Danaher Corporation held its annual shareholder meeting on May 6, 2025, where shareholders elected thirteen directors and approved Ernst & Young LLP as the independent auditor for the year ending December 31, 2025, and the named executive officer compensation on an advisory basis.
2.  Significant shareholder votes against director nominations ranged from 2.78 million to 175.34 million shares, with substantial abstentions and broker non-votes also present.

3. The significant number of votes against some director nominations at the May 6, 2025 shareholder meeting (as high as 175 million shares against one nominee) may signal underlying shareholder dissatisfaction and pose a potential future risk to board stability.
1. Eli Lilly & Co.'s 2025 Annual Meeting on May 5, 2025, saw approximately 89% of outstanding shares voted.

2.  Shareholders approved the compensation of named executive officers (731,376,577 for, 28,008,877 against) and ratified Ernst & Young LLP as the independent auditor for 2025, but rejected proposals to amend the Articles of Incorporation to eliminate the classified board structure and supermajority voting provisions (both failed to receive the required 80% vote).
3.  The failure of the proposals to amend the Articles of Incorporation could impact future governance and shareholder voting power.
1. LKQ Corp held its annual meeting on May 7, 2025, where shareholders elected 11 directors and ratified Deloitte & Touche LLP as the independent auditor for fiscal year 2025.
2.  A shareholder proposal to allow special meetings to be called at a 10% ownership threshold received 196,280,923 votes for and 34,955,255 votes against (as of May 7, 2025).
3.  The advisory vote on executive compensation received 223,117,358 votes for and 12,460,880 votes against (as of May 7, 2025).
1. At the May 8, 2025 Annual Meeting, United Rentals, Inc. stockholders elected all ten nominated directors but rejected a shareholder proposal to improve shareholder written consent.
2.  A significant number of votes were cast against the reelection of Michael J. Kneeland (1,781,445) compared to other directors.
3.  The advisory vote on executive compensation was approved, but with a substantial number of votes (2,537,938) cast against the proposal.
1. Starbucks completed a public offering on May 8, 2025, issuing $1,750,000,000 in senior notes due between 2028 and 2035.
2.  The offering included $750,000,000 of 4.500% Senior Notes due 2028, $500,000,000 of 4.800% Senior Notes due 2030, and $500,000,000 of 5.400% Senior Notes due 2035.

3. Starbucks may be required to repurchase the notes at 101% of principal plus accrued interest if a change of control occurs and the notes are downgraded to below investment grade by Moody's and S&P.

1. BIO-TECHNE Corp.'s net earnings decreased significantly year-over-year to $22.6 million in the quarter ended March 31, 2025, primarily due to a non-recurring arbitration award and litigation charges totaling $38.9 million for the quarter.
2.  The company's second phase of the Wilson Wolf acquisition is expected to cost approximately $1 billion, potentially increasing based on revenue, starting in fiscal year 2026.

3. Despite the net earnings decrease, consolidated net sales increased by 6% year-over-year for the nine months ended March 31, 2025, driven by strong performance in the Diagnostics and Spatial Biology segment.
1. On May 5, 2025, Automatic Data Processing, Inc. issued $1,000,000,000 in 4.750% senior notes due 2032.
2.  The notes were sold at 99.441% of their principal amount, resulting in net proceeds of $994,410,000 to the company (before expenses).

3. The underwriting agreement includes detailed representations and warranties from ADP concerning the legality and accuracy of information in the registration statement and prospectus, as well as indemnification clauses protecting both ADP and the underwriters.
